description: main scenes at center depicting man talking to woman and child in palace, above imagery of beheadings and murder, above imagery of a kidnapping; numbered lines of Sinhalese script in borders in and around the main imagery; side images and inner ring of images depicting invading armies; outer ring depicts trees, animals, and the occassion figures; dish has slightly sloped rim
inscription:
[Central panel, inscriptions 1 - 3]
1. Wrath of King Śrī Vikrama Rāja Siṅha over Ähälepola Kumārihāmi [Wife of
Ähälepola Nilame].
2. [King Śrī Vikrama Rāja Siṅha] commands [Ähälepola] Kumārihāmi to pound
the heads of her children on a rice pounder.
3. [Ähälepola] Kumārihāmi is thrown to Bogambara [Kandy] lake.
[Middle Circle, inscriptions 4 - 14]
4. Molligoḍa Mansion [Valavuva: Residence of a Person of Distinction].
Postmen.
5. Informing [Ähälepola] Nilame [unclear].
6. Saparagamuva [Sabaragamuva] Mansion [Residence of Ähälepola Nilame
in Ratnapura District].
7. [Ähälepola] Nilame in [his] journey to Colombo.
8. Colonial Hardy with [Ähälepola] Nilame.
9. The English Army goes to capture the country [Up-country of Ceylon].
10. The Army of “Śrī” [Vikrama Rāja Siṅha?] or The Army of Väddā.
11. The Army of Väddā shooting [arrows].
12. [Sir Robert] Brownrigg [1812-20] and other chiefs.
13. King in the Upper Room [unclear]
14. King [Śrī Vikrama] Rāja is captured and taken to Colombo.
text: With vividly hammered detail, this large brass dish commemorates the epic fall of the Kingdom of Kandy (1592-1815), the last independent state in Sri Lanka (Ceylon) to succumb to British Crown rule. The design echoes that of Kandyan mural painting, with events staged in a series of illustrated panels, accompanied by brief descriptions chased in Sinhalese. Here, the central scene depicts Kandy’s controversial king, Sri Vikrama Raja Simha, enthroned in his palace in full regalia, demanding retribution for the betrayal of his chief minister Ehelepola (Ähälepola). (The minister is shown in the cartouche on the left, defecting on palanquin to the British capital at Colombo.) Ehelepola’s wife and children were left behind and await their horrific fate: [King Śrī Vikrama Rāja Siṅha] commands [Ähälepola] Kumārihāmi to pound the heads of her children on a rice pounder. [Ähälepola] Kumārihāmi is thrown into Bogambara [Kandy] lake. On the inner rim, rows of British Calvary led by Sir Robert Browning swiftly defeat Vikrama Raja Sinha’s army. The king was deposed on March 2, 1815 and is last seen with his queen in a pavilion in Colombo, just prior to their exile to Vellore, in the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu. Despite the violent narrative, flora and fauna abound—evoking the tropical beauty of the Indian Ocean island which had been storied in the West before the time of Pliny. Moreover, this superb example of 19th C South Asian decorative arts typifies a prevailing tendency of British Crown rule, which was to further legitimize its claim by well publicizing the despotic behaviours of ‘oriental’ kings.
title: Commemorative dish depicting the fall of the Kingdom of Kandy
